citations.narrative:
A four-toed hedgehog was placed in a bin inadvertently fed to a snake. This method of handling animals outside of
enclosures is insufficient to protect animals from harm. Handling protocols must be designed to ensure animal handling is
done as expeditiously and carefully as possible to minimize risk of harm and stress.
Correct by 2/17/24.

A rabbit enclosure was insufficient to keep predators out, resulting in predation by the licensee's dogs. Enclosures unable
to prevent access by other animals may subject contained rabbits to stress and harm. As such, primary enclosures must
be constructed and maintained in good repair to keep other animals out and to protect rabbits from injury.
Correct by 2/17/24.

There was excessive buildup of excreta along the fencing across from the barn in the outdoor portion of the African
Crested porcupine enclosure. Buildup of excreta within enclosures may predispose animals to disease and cause
excessive odor. Excreta must be removed from enclosures as often as necessary to minimize risk of contamination of
animals, minimize disease hazard, and to reduce odor.
Correct by 2/21/24.

General housekeeping around the facility needs to be addressed. There are accumulations of dust and debris, cobwebs,
and other materials throughout the facility. The yard open to the wallaby contains a structure in disrepair. There are
materials stored on top of the chinchilla enclosure and on a shelf over a pig enclosure. Materials may fall off the shelf and
into the pig enclosure, exposing them to injury. There are accumulations of trash in multiple areas around the premises
that promote breeding and living areas for rodents and pests.
Buildings and grounds must be kept clean and in good repair to protect animals from injury and facilitate proper
husbandry. Further, accumulations of trash must be placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect
animals.
Correct by 3/13/24.

The current method of pest control is insufficient to mitigate and reduce flies in the food preparation area. Flies and pests
predispose diets to spoilage and contamination. Additional mitigation efforts are needed to provide for a safe and effective
program for control of insects.
Correct by 2/29/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
A four-toed hedgehog was placed in a bin inadvertently fed to a snake. This method of handling animals outside of 
enclosures is insufficient to protect animals from harm. Handling protocols must be designed to ensure animal handling is 
done as expeditiously and carefully as possible to minimize risk of harm and stress.  
 
Correct by 2/17/24. 
3.53(a)(1)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
A rabbit enclosure was insufficient to keep predators out, resulting in predation by the licensee's dogs. Enclosures unable 
to prevent access by other animals may subject contained rabbits to stress and harm. As such, primary enclosures must 
be constructed and maintained in good repair to keep other animals out and to protect rabbits from injury. 
 
Correct by 2/17/24. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
There was excessive buildup of excreta along the fencing across from the barn in the outdoor portion of the African 
Crested porcupine enclosure. Buildup of excreta within enclosures may predispose animals to disease and cause 
excessive odor. Excreta must be removed from enclosures as often as necessary to minimize risk of contamination of 
animals, minimize disease hazard, and to reduce odor.  
 
Correct by 2/21/24. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
General housekeeping around the facility needs to be addressed. There are accumulations of dust and debris, cobwebs, 
and other materials throughout the facility. The yard open to the wallaby contains a structure in disrepair. There are

materials stored on top of the chinchilla enclosure and on a shelf over a pig enclosure. Materials may fall off the shelf and 
into the pig enclosure, exposing them to injury. There are accumulations of trash in multiple areas around the premises 
that promote breeding and living areas for rodents and pests.  
 
Buildings and grounds must be kept clean and in good repair to protect animals from injury and facilitate proper 
husbandry. Further, accumulations of trash must be placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect 
animals. 
 
Correct by 3/13/24. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
The current method of pest control is insufficient to mitigate and reduce flies in the food preparation area. Flies and pests 
predispose diets to spoilage and contamination. Additional mitigation efforts are needed to provide for a safe and effective 
program for control of insects. 
 
Correct by 2/29/24. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
